job_title: Dietetic Technician, Registered in Shelby, NC
pros:
-Atrium has a name for itself in the greater Charlotte, NC area among healthcare hopefuls as a great place to work; the pay is great for nursing staff and doctors/providers. 
-They are always hiring, and willing to hire new grads fresh off the graduation stage.
-The company is working diligently towards DEI in the workplace.
-Atrium offers tuition assistance, but unless you are working towards a nursing degree is it difficult to get. You can also use it for continuing education credits (seminars, webinars, etc.), which is easier to get.
-The Recognition and Rewards platform is, or can be, a great way to show appreciation to employees. Every time I received a WOW card from family or eCard from my colleagues or manager, I realized my value.
cons:
-Pay is horrendous for anyone outside nursing. 
-They pick and choose who will get compensation for commuting; I worked a re-deployment assignment alongside someone who lived closer than I did and that employee received mileage pay for their re-deployment assignments. 
-If you aren't from the immediate area you are working, you will never break the code to make work friends. It was the loneliest place to work ever. 
-Calling employees "teammates" (and having supervisors and managers who correct you when you don't use the terminology) is so demeaning and childish. 
-Nepotism is rampant. Management will hire immediate family into roles they are unqualified for, including roles that require certifications. 
-The VIA awards (which come with points that can be redeemed for gift cards or pretty decent gifts) went to the same favorited people in administration. VIA awards have to be approved, so if someone outside the favorite clique was nominated, they were generally declined. 
-Atrium's continuous moves towards overtaking other healthcare facilities is atrocious. They are turning into a healthcare "not-for-profit" conglomerate that had a revenue of $10.7 billion dollars in 2019; failed to provide crisis pay for employees during the COVID-19 pandemic; cut annual COL raises in 2021; and still gave the CEO a 9% increase in pay in Jan 2021 (he received a 20% increase in pay in Jan 2020).
-Atrium partially owns the employees' insurance provider (MedCost) and yet it is barely affordable. For the 2 years I was working there, the prescription "benefits" constantly changed coverage, which happened to affect the medications I was taking every time. The LiveWELL incentives were impossible to obtain, and never posted to your spending account. 
-Insurance barely offers any mental health coverage, and throughout the COVID-19 pandemic Atrium touted their Code Lavender "mental health support", which is just a phone number to call when you are stressed out. Frequently, someone would drop off a container of cotton balls soaked in lavender oil and a paper asking us to write our name down if we wanted someone to pray for us with the phone number at the bottom of the page.

cons: All the money goes to upper level management and the CEO, Michael Tarwater.  Lower level employees get virtually nothing.  Raises are capped at around 1%.  There is no chance for advancement unless you are prepared to kiss upper management's ring or you know someone.  I have never worked for a company this dysfunctional nor have I ever been this unhappy at a position.  For a CEO of a non-profit organization to get $4 million between salary and bonuses, fly the company jet for personal business, and then tell his employees there is not enough money for decent raises is just disgusting.  If you are planning to work in upper level management it is a great company but for all the people that make the money, it is just not worth it.

pros: Good social mission within the community, great patient care, lots of good people who work hard to make a difference on the clinical and non-clinical sides.
cons: Non-clinical side is largely disregarded, and typically gets the lowest caliber of support from central resource areas like HR, IT, etc. Comp and benefits really sub par, especially PTO - yet the company believes it can attract top talent. Virtually no commitment to leadership or staff development - and it shows. A huge, slow moving bureaucracy which resists transformative, meaningful change, and is obsessed with pedigree (MBAs, Six Sigma Black Belt, etc) over actual skills and achievements.

pros: Some decent benefits and personal growth.
cons: Worked in this organization for over 9 years, hourly pay rate less than nine dollars. The only real perks you have are your healthcare insurance, if you can afford it. Good thing I have a spouse and a supportive family or I might be living under a bridge!  Management likes to tell you how "excellent" your work is, but only if they need you to do "MORE WORK" while they are steady cutting your hours. I guess they think hourly employees are too stupid to see what's going on!

review_title: The system has went downhill fast
pros: The teamwork of coworkers is great and the pay is okay.
cons: Too much favoritism among management towards employees as they over look hardworking dedicated employees and just keep moving up others that don't deserve to be promoted and is done so just because they like them. The CEO is horrible and is running the system in the ground as a long time employee it's sad to see where the system is heading. He has politicized the work place and shown that he is all about the money and seems he is the only one making plenty.

pros: After a few years of dealing with the worst examples of self-important leadership I have had in my career, fortunate to now have an insightful and savvy supervisor.  Current leader shares information as appropriate and collaborates with all of his direct reports. It's a team-directed approach that capitalizes on individual expertise. Organization also added new executive leadership in past few years that pays attention to employee survey feedback. How refreshing.
cons: Like most jobs, advancement is dependent on your boss,  leadership mentor, and company M&A activity. Frustrating when all gets put on hold while awaiting regulatory determination on next organization M&A.  Many executives who were not embracing new approaches are now gone- just a couple more to go.

review_title: I was with CHS for nearly 23 years and witness a great deal of growth & development in the organization.
job_title: Administrative Dtr for Clinical Research & Prevention SHVI in Charlotte, NC
pros: CHS does a great deal of good work in the community and provides services to those who otherwise might not have access to appropriate healthcare.  In general I would say that the pay and benefits are competitive and the culture is good though a good deal of the cultural stuff is more rhetoric that action.
cons:
Administrative staff from the AVP level up are completely detached for the patients and the people that care for the patients and seem to view patients more as a business relationship that people
with a problem with the organization can assist them with.

pros: Great multifunctional collaborative teams, healthcare services across the continuum, exceptional staff throughout business units
cons: Numerous staff and budget cuts with ongoing executive push for growth; lack of executive support for research, which has led to poor resources (tools, staff) for research-involved physicians and administration; minimal communications and marketing support for research.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Charlotte, NC
pros: Teamwork on my unit is nice. Staff does actually care about patient care. This is. Trauma level one, so you work with amazing people and learn a lot!
cons: Pay is bad, staffing is not great, the guys up top make a lot and don’t seem to care about any of the staff. Holiday requirements are more than other hospitals I’ve worked for as well. Holiday pay and OT pay isn’t great. Holiday pay is just an extra $10/hr. For a trauma level 1 hospital that has its own college of nursing you’d think they’d want to pay competitively to keep and recruit the best. But they don’t.

review_title: Depends on what unit you work, shift, team leader, manager, etc.
pros:
Competitive salaries. 
Float nurses lucky enough to be assigned to a floor with a dedicated team leader, count your blessings, for they are rare. I felt like part of a team in those instances. If I could have gotten permanent placement to those particular units, I would have accepted.
cons: Most units I've worked on the staff offered little assist/direction to floaters. They seemed  more focused on the social aspects of the job, eg: lunch, gossip, cell phones, etc, rather than patient care. Also, being new to the Florence, South Carolina area, I was reminded of it daily, and not in a good way.

pros: Pay scale is improving. Policies and protocols are now in place that weren't when I started. Most people that you work with are nice, and helpful. Immediate managers are good.
cons: Closing offices . Gave me a big pay raise, then closed the office. I will not be able to get a position that pays what I am making now, if and when, I transfer. Also, a position was posted that didn't really exist as the funding for it never materialized. Management says one thing, than the plan changes. You have to be ready for your next move. System becoming huge, and doctors are no longer the drivers of their practice. Insurance deductible for member +one is outrageous for a self insured entity!

pros: After 25 years here, I can say this hospital system is a great place to work and I'm lucky to have had such a wonderful experience!  I have worked in 5 different departments (by choice) and learned so much.  Some managers have been better than others, but you have that in every company.  I have worked with some really smart, caring physicians and nurses who really put patient care first.
cons: Our insurance plan is changing next year and will be much more expensive - seems ironic that employees of a health care system don't have a good, affordable health insurance plan!

pros: Benefits, offer some of the best benefits overall. Including healthcare, retirement and life insurance.
cons: System is so big and growing so fast, that you get lost in the numbers. Quality of care is the #1 priority, fix the problems and your major facilities before you expand and create those problems elsewhere. Salaries compared to other local hospitals just doesn't meet expected or median salary ranges.

pros: You can self schedule. It's a 3 day work week.
cons: Sadly management is  only interested in having RNs or RTs. This is the ONLY system that does not allow their paramedics to fly in any type of aircraft. When I left my previous system, I was a senior medic and well respected. Here I have been referred to as....just a medic......a driver.....others have refused to work with our most experienced medics in critical care configurations, requesting another RT for transport. This type of disrespectful behavior is common place.

pros: Discounts, PTO, End of Year Bonuses, Balance between work and life, good pay
cons: Opportunities for advancement with the system is not promising. It feels like Internal employees are not given a chance to be heard regarding moving up.

pros: There isn't  any pros anymore! The reviews that are saying CHS live well is great, and benefits are wonderful, are employees whom work in the HR offices..
cons:
The lab has the biggest turnover in the hospital, phlebotomist often work alone, causing patients lab work to late, and there is times when a patients labs are missed!! no one person can handle ICU, Code Blues, Rapid Responses, all floors and the ED!! the lab is short by 7 people and they will not replace them.
  Management changes the schedules to fit their needs, they could care less about your home life.  We work more days with less hours so we don't have overtime. benefits are horrible. We do the job of three and get paid for one.

pros: Large company with tons of resources. Did my clinical rotation for nursing school at CMC Main and liked it for the most part.
cons: As with most nursing units there will always be "clicks". Downside to this company is that when I was enrolled in their nursing school (before I switched and graduated from another local school) they kicked me out and put me down as a "no rehire" because I informed my professors that I wanted to attend my grandmothers funeral. I grew up in a large tight knight family and have strong family values. It's horrible that taking 1-3 days off (my family is on the west coast) for a death of a close family member would bar me for life of any opportunities at this corporation. The nursing instructors were incredibly rude and disrespectful.

pros: Great experience at a level 1 trauma center! Most managers are flexible and like to work with the staff they have, meaning not punitive and allow for a good work life balance. There are lots of positions to move into and ways to advance on the clinical ladder.
cons: Although there seems to be job openings all the time, it's sometimes hard to transfer even when your "in the system" already. I think HR takes the screening process to the extreme, and don't take into account that you have to start somewhere. Also because CMC is apart of the big CHS system, monetary compensation is lacking because they take over all the competition

review_title: Would go elsewhere if had a choice
pros: Job security, insurance, growing company
cons: Poor management at several of the locations I have worked. HR is unwilling to help unhappy employees. Minimal pay increases with increasing work load each year and constant under staffing issues. Organization rules are extremely strict and some are just ridiculous. Most  depts don't allow overtime.Aside from Novant system there are no other options for medical jobs because CHS owns everything in this area. Therefore they can treat employees indifferently and pay less than deserved.

pros: Team of nurses work great together.  Supplies for patients readily available. Nursing supervisors readily available for emergencies. Calling a Rapid Response team was not discouraged. Nursing team tried hard not to assign more than 6 patients per nurse in medsurg.
cons: Missing breaks and/or lunch was commonplace. Lowest paying system in the area. Pay raises were very small. Vacation time is hard to get on weekends. Constantly being asked to work overtime. Nurses required to float to other medsurg units on a rotating basis, as needed. Shift differential is not high enough for nurses to want to remain on nights. There is a long waiting list for days.

job_title: Simulation Training Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: The pay is alright and you get time off for going over hours sometimes/get comp time. I love the job itself too.
cons: Management is awful. Mine is sexist and can’t say thank you for anything. I was injured on the job because management went out drinking during work hours and excused everyone else to leave. They don’t fire coworkers who don’t work, which means you have to work enough to cover them if you want to do a good job. A lot of late nights, early mornings, and weekend labs.

review_title: Not a great place to work for maintenance/ skilled trade workers.
pros: A check, steady income is the only thing that makes this job worth coming to. There aren't too many pros to this position.
cons: Dealing with immature old men, who constantly complain about having to do something, the maintenance department is the bottom of the food chain. Administration has favorites and cater to them more than other employees. Extremely political workplace. Schedule sucks. Tons of responsibilities honestly do not know all that we are responsible for. You come in and do the same thing every day.

pros: Decent benefits. Some of the people are nice. There are a few good managers. The patients are really sweet and they make coming into work worth it.
cons: They low ball you with pay, they don’t care about staff, the doctors get away with everything and it’s always your fault, management doesn’t take up for staff. Drama, not what I thought this job would be like at all. MAs are under appreciated here. It’s sad but true.

pros: PTO, Good Benefits (i.e. employee medical insurance=$12/pay period-w/no kids, 401k match, cheap dental & vision=$5-7), Holidays off (depending your location), friendly/peppy staff, point system=receiving points to buy stuff from company/employee site (i.e 300 points=bag/coffee maker/etc.)
cons: Management attempts to delegate unpaid activities  (i.e Huddles/meetings/pulling the weight of others-->supervisory work*) if you start leading activities then choose to stop, you'll be penalized. Your volunteer effort becomes a mandatory task. The company has its own Health Insurance called Medcost. so if you get insurance, you're basically paying the company back. Medcost is cheap for employees but expensive if you have kids (adds on about $115 for children)  however, the more kids you have the better deal (same price for having 1 child or 4). Another Con, overly peppy employees & somewhat prying.

review_title: In corporate IT, it's who you know, not what you know.
pros: Flexible hours, telecommute, decent healthcare if you use CMC physicians. If you want to come in and do your daily tasks and then go home, you can comfortably do that here for 40 years, with your 2% annual increase and total job security.
cons: Pay is low for non-clinical positions, IT training is hard to come by, management is uninformed on most things, using non-CMC healthcare will cost you. If you are looking for a career with growth potential, you'll be hard pressed to find it in IT - though they re-org every year just for the sake of change, the rate of promotion is sorely lacking.

pros: Some nice and fantastic people work here.
cons:
This company owns the for-profit insurance company, Medcost, which provides the employee benefit. You get only one selection, a High Deductible Health Plan, that is very expensive and requires employees to use its own facilities and doctors. Basically, don't ever get sick if you work here.

Positions are left vacant for too long, some never get filled.

Unless you know someone, you will most likely not get a job here.  Even if you do know someone, you will still have to wait months to get in.

Grandfathered employees have better benefits than newer employees.

pros: Compensation in my department is not bad, but could always be better.  PTO is great.  Wellness incentives with insurance.
cons:
Management has no clinical experience.  Loyalty and longevity are rewarded over hard work - only 2% annual raise no matter how productive and efficient you are.  Things move very slowly here - changes are slow.  Lots of employees have become complacent and have lost their energy.  However, their longevity is financially rewarded.

Health insurance is awful!  Will only have HSA option in 2016 :(

pros: Caring - Our providers do the best possible job in the worst of healthcare reform circumstances, with budget cuts and a hiring freeze, clinicians #1 aim is still patient care. Kudos.
cons: Commitment, Teamwork, Integrity - you don't get to pick & choose these characteristics, you either have them or you don't, we do a good job talking about them but not so good on the overall action.

pros: I am a PRN (as needed) employee and can travel to different hospitals to get the hours I need and want. The requirements are only to work 2 eight-hour shifts per 2 weeks, and 2 weekend days per month. Also, you must work 2 holidays out of Thanksgiving, Black Friday, Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, New Year's Eve and New Year's Day. Starting pay is $16/hr on 1st shift Mon - Fri. $17.25 for 2nd shift Mon. - Fri., and $18/hr on the weekends.
cons: I have yet to run into any Cons in my job. This means with my management team and co-workers across 5 hospitals that I have worked at so far.

pros:
There are many opportunities for continuous growth and advancement.  
The company offers a solid benefits package.  
The potential for job stability is phenomenal.  
There are some truly exceptional people who are associated with this organization who are committed to doing the right thing each and every day.
cons:
The organization has experienced a tremendous amount of growth and development during recent years.  The extreme growth has presented some challenges as the communication and processes have struggled to keep up with the changes.  

There are also some individuals who are not exceptional leaders yet year after year they continue to act in the same inappropriate and unprofessional manner.

pros: Workers are committed to patients.  Despite the challenges in their work day the employees do really care and try their best to provide excellent care.  From that perspective I have the highest confidence in the care being delivered.  Very highly skilled staff.  Salaries are middle of the road nationally.  Not great and not terrible.
cons: Administration micro-manages to the extent that employee contributions are minimized and ineffective.  There is no workplace pride or ownership because employees are devalued.  There is an adversarial culture between leaders and clinical workers including physicians.  Physician leadership is lip-speak only since administration makes all the decisions and physician leaders are simply the messengers.

review_title: Great to the community and employees
pros: Experienced management, high quality care and organized with high standards, able to meet high demand
cons: Expanding far beyond Charlotte and surrounding areas, potential for more bureaucracy

review_title: A healthcare company that is growing rapidly, even in tough times.
pros: The growth of the company provide professional growth opportunities for employees.  And, job security is much better than in other companies and industries.

review_title: Big company that has still managed to retain a small-company feel.

cons: Art the end of the day, this is still a large healthcare company, so there are aspects of CHS that feel very corporate.

review_title: Overall a good place to work, not as generous with benefits as previous yrs but this seems to be the trend in healthcare

pros:

Great hours once you gain some seniority

The rest of the building or teams have greater flexibility and able to manager their workflow better. If it''s a Monday, be prepared to come in, sit down and answer calls back to back to back.

Security lives by the ER and is rarely seen in the employee parking lots nor in the hospital lobby.  No cameras in the employee lots.

review_title: If you are in the "Click" with management, you will advance and do well with the system

Wake up CHS!!!!

pros: The people are really amazing. They really care about their work and their coworkers. It feels like family. There are also many opportunities to volunteer with each other as well.  The new CEO is great and is changing the whole landscape of the organization, expanding the coverage to more and more people, which is really awesome.

Depending on your department, the opportunities for advancement can be limited. review_title: Carolina is the best company I have ever worked for. The benefits are something awesome!

review_title: Decent place to work, but the large size can be discouraging
pros: Excellent patient care provided here, feel good about being part of the company's mission. Enjoy working with most people here. Many opportunities to move around and eventually up within the company. There is a definite push for employee engagement and retention, and the company does try to keep employees happy, even in these challenging financial times for healthcare in this country and in NC. In recent years, there has been more flexibility in work life balance options for employees, including work from home opportunities and chances to have more flexible schedules.
cons:
Politics. Also, so many layers of management dilute the ability for managers to actually accomplish things or make decisions on their own. Managers, directors, AVPs, VPs, SVPs, EVPs, President, and then CEO...there must be another layer in there because I know that, as a manager, I am considered "level 9", which means that's how many layers I have to go through to get approval on any decisions for my team. Therefore, all changes are made at a snail's pace, if at all. This can be frustrating and de-motivating. 

Also, I know that healthcare benefits are probably worsening for most people, but the benefits offered here were the worst I had ever seen in the 15+ years I've been working in healthcare, and during the time since I started at CHS back in the mid 2000s, my benefits have worsened every year, with this year being the absolute worst (now there is zero choice: everyone has a high deductible plan and has to pay thousands before the co-insurance benefits kick in, at which point we still pay 30% of everything). I just paid over $200 for a prescription that cost me $4 several years ago (and, my husband still pays $4 for his prescriptions, because he is on his own separate plan. He takes one of the same medications that I do, yet his insurance pays for his medicine. He is an engineer. You'd think working in the largest healthcare institution in the state might get you decent health benefits, but nope, not the case).

pros: The job is fine. Good experience, great doctors, opportunities to learn and advance.
cons: They took our health insurance away and replaced it with something that basically makes us uninsured. It's killing my family and many of my coworkers have left or are planning to leave for this reason. We have complained but were told this would not change somget used to it. Our pay does not allow us to cover medical bills out of pocket. Morale is at a low point everywhere.

pros: I can not think of any. Everything has gotten worse since CHS has taken over. I thought the insurance would be better but the pharmacy benefits are very restricitive. Retirement plan is adequate.
cons: They keep adding responsibilities without change in compensation. Unsafe work practices. I feel I am putting my medical license on the line. Thinking about reporting everything to the medical board if things dont get better soon. Physician leaders are corporate representatives pushing the corporate agenda. They don't listen to your opinion. If you do have an opinion, its best kept to yourself. If not youre considered disruptive and they make it very difficult for you to stay.

review_title: All the negatives of "corporate" without the money of corporate...
pros: It's Carolinas HealthCare System, which means it's pretty much the premier care provider in the Southeast and will look good on your resume.
cons:
I don't work there anymore and I can ONLY speak to the corporate side, but it's a pretty negative environment and the pay is below average. Lots of turnover due to pay, low morale, lack of upward mobility and, at least in my opinion, lots of inexperienced managers who had simply snuggled up in one way or the other to the people that hired them. This is how it is at most corporate offices, granted, but it's reallllly bad at CHS. Plenty of tenured, 35-55 year old people who are put under the control of  much younger, inexperienced managers who upper management feels are less threatening. Tons of talent wastes away/walks out the door because many of the managers suppress ideas, use scare tactics and micromanage because they're terrified of being upstaged by their subordinates. That being said, if you want to be a manager or above here and you have "impressive" credentials from another industry, you probably have a pretty good shot.

There's also a bit of a "grass-is-greener" mindset where upper level management will automatically look outside of the organization for new leaders instead of promoting proven workers from within. The consequences are often new managers from other industries who are now supervising tenured employees that already know the healthcare industry inside-and-out. This inevitably leads to insecurity among management, which leads to micromanagement, unwarranted criticism and mistreatment of employees, etc. etc. 

The SVP position tends to recycle frequently (every 2-3 years) due to high-stress, sub-average pay, which means every time a new SVP takes over, he or she will assuredly want to hire "their people" while intentionally marginalizing potential "threat employees" within the workplace and beginning the cycle again. This is what leads to heavy turnover and the absence of any kind of sustained growth.

pros: The teamwork that is seen within our office is excellent. Everyone is always willing to support and encourage one another. The benefits of tuition reimbursement is nice, as well as employee referral bonuses.
cons: The insurance benefits are not the greatest as it was 10+ years ago.  Rarely get recognized for the over and beyond work that you do. Hourly and salary pay rate are ridiculous as well as the raises are not well at all.

review_title: Too many negative changes with new CEO, little job security
pros: A well-established healthcare company in the Charlotte area with a good historical reputation.  Large employer with opportunities to move around to different hospitals and/or departments.
cons:
Little job security following Mr. Gene Woods taking the reigns as CEO.  Multiple high level (VP, Senior VP, etc.) executives have been removed or suddenly resigned.  This has trickled down to the lower levels and has really raised a consistent level of unease and ‘fear’ resulting in lost productivity.

Key positions are currently vacant or filled with an ‘acting’ executive (President of Carolinas Medical Center Main/Central Division {acting}, Chief Medical Officer of Mercy {vacant} to name a couple).  

Communication is very lacking system-wide.  Information isn’t passed down to the frontline teammates, leadership doesn’t do as good of a job as they should to ensure that situations/concerns are dealt with in a timely and appropriate manner.

Human Resources representatives provide inaccurate information on fairly regular basis.  Some from this department seem to respond based on what they think it should be without researching the information/policy to confirm.  

Employee parking at Carolinas Medical Center Main is very problematic.  Though it would cost a lot of money to add additional parking spots, something needs to be done to speed up parking.  It is normal for it to take 15 minutes to find a parking spot in the garage.

Health benefits are really poor.  What makes it worse is this is a healthcare company.  I am not sure what the reasoning is for the poor coverage but it is bad.  I know of at least a dozen former teammates that left to go to Novant to get better coverage.  I also know of at least three teammates that go to the VA for their healthcare needs instead of using their Atrium insurance.

An overall opinion that I heard time-and-time again was that the decision being made were not in the best interest of the employees/teammates.  Specifically the multi-million dollar name change to Atrium Health and removing the Mecklenburg Medical Group.  There are teammates on the fence on if changing anesthesia providers will actually reduce the cost that our patients pay.
